Description.val:
The T-38 is a twin engine, two seat (tandem), supersonic jet trainer used by Air Education Training Command as an advanced trainer in Specialized Undergraduate Pilot Training.  Modifications are budgeted to enhance operational capability while improving flight safety, reliability, and maintainability.  There are currently 505 T-38's in the Air Force inventory (53 T-38A, 6 AT-38B and 446 T-38C) with 5 T-38C's pending removal.  The T-38 first entered service in 1960 and the average age is over 50 years old.  The T-38 was designed with a 7,000 hour service life.  Aircraft are now in their third service life and are sustained by upgrades and service life extensions.  Funding may be used to address Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material shortages DMSMS) issues.

Funding for this exhibit contained in PE 0804741F.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Name.val: Aircraft Modification Kits:INSTALL KITS Group A (Active)

Description.val:
Pacer Classic III (PCIII) is a depot-level modification program which replaces known life-limited components and ensures structural sustainment of 180 T-38C aircraft which are at high risk of grounding. Timely modifications will ensure continued execution of the Air Education and Training Command (AETC) advanced undergraduate pilot training mission. PCIII will replace major structural components within the aircraft fuselage including major longerons, bulkhead/formers, internal skins and structural floors. These modifications have been categorized as Safety of Flight and determined by HQ Air Force Materiel Command to be required to correct material deficiencies to ensure safety of personnel, systems or equipment. If uncorrected, the hazard will ground the system or equipment, restrict flight or ground operations, or result in unacceptable risk to personnel. PCIII program requirements are documented in Air Force Form 1067: AETC 2016-037. PC III installations will be performed by the 309 Maintenance Wing geographically separated unit at Randolph AFB, TX.

Milestone/Development Status

Production and deployment underway.

Name.val: VHF Nav/Comm Radios:INSTALL KITS Group A (Active)

Description.val:
The T-38C Avionics Upgrade Program installed a "Glass Cockpit" into the T-38 jet trainer and re-designated the upgraded aircraft from the T-38A/B to the T-38C model.  The Avionics Upgrade Program modification was completed in 2007 and utilized a Commercial Off-The-Shelf/Non-Developmental Item approach to acquire kits.  The system is in the operations and maintenance phase.  Off-equipment repair of the Line Replaceable Units, engineering and software support services is provided via Contractor Logistics Support.  Contract, FA8211-12-C-0001, identified significant obsolescence issues with the Heads-Up Display system, the Mission Display Processor, Very High Frequency Communication receiver transmitter and the Very High Frequency Navigation radio.

Contract #FA8211-16-D-0001 was awarded 8 January 2016. The contract is a Type D Indefinite Delivery, Indefinite Quantity contract competitively awarded to address T-38C avionics system obsolescence issues and provide Contractor Logistics Support follow-on contract support. Avionics system Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages mitigation efforts began immediately upon award and the follow-on Contractor Logistics Support effort began(FA8211-12-C-0001), 1 April 2017.

Mitigation plans include the following: The program began non-recurring development in FY2016 for a replacement Mission Display Processor, Very High Frequency Communication receiver transmitter and the Very High Frequency Navigation radio and refurbishment of the Heads-Up Display System.  Procurement of the Mission Display Processor, Very High Frequency Communication receiver transmitter and the Very High Frequency Navigation radio began in FY2016.  Heads-Up Display System and ADS-B system procurement began in FY2017.

The Federal Aviation Administration has mandated that all aircraft flying in Federal Aviation Administration controlled air space be equipped with Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) Out equipment by 1 January 2020.  The T-38C program began development and integration of a solution upon FA8211-16-D-0001 contract award in January 2016 and system procurement began in FY2017.  The program has incentivized the contractor to meet the 01 January 2020 FAA mandate.    All USAF ADS-B kit buys have been completed. The contracted schedule has all T-38C aircraft ADS-B compliant by 12 February 2020.  Approximately 50 aircraft will not meet mandate based on the current schedule.  The primary schedule driver is the Radio Frequency Authorization process which could take up to a year after developmental test completion.

Milestone/Development Status

All programs, Mission Display Processor,Heads-Up Display,Very High Frequency Radios and ADS-B, are in integration and test on the Systems Integration Lab at Boeing St. Louis.  Developmental Test at Edwards will begin by the 2nd quarter of FY18.

The Government has a new requirement to comply with the Federal Aviation Administration mandate that all aircraft operating in Classes A, B, C, and certain Class E airspaces (above 18,000 feet and civil aviation traffic areas) beyond 1 January 2020 be equipped with Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast(ADS-B) compliant transponders. The 59 T-38A and AT-38B model aircraft operated by Air Combat Command and Air Force Global Strike Command do not currently have ADS-B capability and require a replacement transponder to meet the ADS-B mandate. 

The T-38 Program Office has identified Government owned assets, the Raytheon APX-119 transponder, that provides the most supportable and lowest risk solution to meeting the Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast requirement time frame. To achieve integration of the APX-119 transponders into the T-38A/B aircraft, the Government must contract to modify the proprietary hardware interfaces to integrate a position source and make the necessary modifications to the transponder's proprietary firmware.   

Integration will include developing and providing the source data for Air Force technical manuals, flight manuals, and aircraft drawings.  The integration requirement provides for the "A" kit hardware development, procurement, and delivery, Time Compliance Technical Order development, and modification of a prototype aircraft.  The "B" kit will consist of the modified Line Replaceable Unit and control box. There is a FY18 spare requirement in the amount of $1.424M.  12 APX-119 RTs, 12 Control Boxes and 12 personality modules.

The contract was awarded to The Raytheon Company 17 May 2017. System development and aircraft integration has started.

Milestone/Development Status

Contract awarded 17 May 2017.  System development and aircraft integration has started.
